description: In this series, Mike explores several tools that are commonly used for Penetration Testing. He shows how the tools work, and explore their functionality. He also demonstrates how to create your own tools, like loading Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7 and creating your own PwnPad.
descriptionMD: In this series, Mike explores several tools that are commonly used for Penetration Testing. He shows how the tools work, and explore their functionality. He also demonstrates how to create your own tools, like loading Kali Nethunter on a Nexus 7 and creating your own PwnPad.
name: Security Tech Skills (2017)
subtitle: Commonly used penetration tools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at host discovery using the venerable Nmap scanner in both Linux and Windows.
episodes.title: Host Discovery
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:00.942
Welcome to ITPRO TV.

2
00:00:00.942 --> 00:00:02.300
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.300 --> 00:00:04.636
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:04.636 --> 00:00:07.998
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:07.998 --> 00:00:10.912
>> You're watching ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:10.912 --> 00:00:13.286
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:13.286 --> 00:00:16.386
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO TV.

8
00:00:16.386 --> 00:00:21.870
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and for
this episode we're having our inaugural

9
00:00:21.870 --> 00:00:24.880
episode of our Security Tech Skill course.

10
00:00:24.880 --> 00:00:27.720
And we've been working hard to bring this
to you because we know this is something

11
00:00:27.720 --> 00:00:32.120
you guys are really interested in,
as am I and the person joining me.

12
00:00:32.120 --> 00:00:33.830
Our good friend Mr. Mike Rodrick.

13
00:00:33.830 --> 00:00:35.010
Mike, how's it going man?

14
00:00:35.010 --> 00:00:36.330
>> It's going great Daniel,
glad to be here.

15
00:00:36.330 --> 00:00:39.480
Excited as well, because it is fun stuff.

16
00:00:39.480 --> 00:00:42.110
>> It is.
>> You know it is exciting kind of stuff.

17
00:00:42.110 --> 00:00:43.980
But it's also important stuff.

18
00:00:43.980 --> 00:00:46.170
It's stuff that hopefully
you'll be able to use.

19
00:00:46.170 --> 00:00:49.770
If you're getting into security,
if your job has come to you and

20
00:00:49.770 --> 00:00:54.320
say we need you to be kind of that guy and
gal and

21
00:00:54.320 --> 00:00:59.010
help protect our network then there's some
basic skills that you're going to need.

22
00:00:59.010 --> 00:01:01.620
And that's really what we
want to cover in this series.

23
00:01:01.620 --> 00:01:04.770
Some of the skills you should just have,
the basics.

24
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:07.700
We're not talking about going out and
writing scripts and

25
00:01:07.700 --> 00:01:09.180
things like that just yet.

26
00:01:09.180 --> 00:01:11.630
We have courses for that,
and that is fun as well.

27
00:01:11.630 --> 00:01:15.030
But here we want to get your feet
wet in the world of security and

28
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:17.410
teach you some of
the skills that you need.

29
00:01:17.410 --> 00:01:18.460
In this inaugural episode,

30
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:22.410
we're going to learn how to do
something known as host discovery.

31
00:01:22.410 --> 00:01:26.550
And what we really mean by that is
we need to go out to our network and

32
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:27.735
we need to find out what's there.

33
00:01:27.735 --> 00:01:33.350
And there's several reasons that we would
want to know what's on our network.

34
00:01:33.350 --> 00:01:38.219
We need to know what host we have,
what clients we have on the network,

35
00:01:38.219 --> 00:01:41.536
what servers,
what access points were there.

36
00:01:41.536 --> 00:01:45.628
And we need to make sure not only you're
gonna know what should be there but

37
00:01:45.628 --> 00:01:49.380
we are also looking for
things that maybe shouldn't be there.

38
00:01:49.380 --> 00:01:52.955
All right, that strange machine
on the network, that's got and

39
00:01:52.955 --> 00:01:55.620
IP address that's outside
of your DHCP scope.

40
00:01:55.620 --> 00:02:00.080
May be it's in the right subnet but it's
not in your scope of dynamic addresses.

41
00:02:00.080 --> 00:02:01.720
And so, what is it?

42
00:02:01.720 --> 00:02:02.710
Where did it come from?

43
00:02:02.710 --> 00:02:06.030
>> So, Mike you are not talking about
us walking around room to room,

44
00:02:06.030 --> 00:02:09.540
table to table with a pen and
a pad of paper going, yes, that is ours.

45
00:02:09.540 --> 00:02:11.170
Yes that printer is ours.

46
00:02:11.170 --> 00:02:12.810
Okay who brought in the access plane.

47
00:02:12.810 --> 00:02:15.380
Not that that's not a viable solution.

48
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:15.910
>> Yeah it is.

49
00:02:15.910 --> 00:02:21.570
>> It can be right but we're talking
about using a tool to find these things.

50
00:02:21.570 --> 00:02:23.430
>> Exactly and I like that.

51
00:02:23.430 --> 00:02:26.790
I mean there is something to be said for
doing a physical look,

52
00:02:26.790 --> 00:02:29.660
it's something that you're
gonna have to do periodically.

53
00:02:29.660 --> 00:02:33.860
When you're doing your wireless networks
and you're looking for dead spots or

54
00:02:33.860 --> 00:02:37.120
rogue access points, you'll probably
will do a little walking around then.

55
00:02:37.120 --> 00:02:39.150
Maybe with your little cart,
your laptop and go rolling around,

56
00:02:39.150 --> 00:02:40.760
whatever you gotta do.

57
00:02:40.760 --> 00:02:44.830
But yes, here we're gonna be talking about
kind of using the network to go out and

58
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:45.940
see what's out there.

59
00:02:45.940 --> 00:02:48.822
And we're gonna be using
a tool known as Nmap.

60
00:02:48.822 --> 00:02:55.400
Now Nmap is a fantastic program, been
around for a long time, and it does a lot.

61
00:02:55.400 --> 00:03:00.340
It's a port scanner, but
it can also do host discovery.

62
00:03:00.340 --> 00:03:03.990
It can look at services and
it can do OS Detection-

63
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:04.938
>> Makes julienne fries.

64
00:03:04.938 --> 00:03:05.456
>> It does.

65
00:03:05.456 --> 00:03:08.060
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you get it set up right, and

66
00:03:08.060 --> 00:03:12.275
you gotta really tweak that config file
to get those julienne fries just right.

67
00:03:12.275 --> 00:03:15.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> Doing host discovery is very simple,

68
00:03:15.520 --> 00:03:20.690
and Nmap itself is a very powerful tool,
but it's relatively easy to work with.

69
00:03:20.690 --> 00:03:23.830
It's got its own scripting language,
it is extremely powerful.

70
00:03:23.830 --> 00:03:26.530
But like I said here we just want
to kind of start off easy and

71
00:03:26.530 --> 00:03:29.520
we're going to take a look at
just doing some host discovery.

72
00:03:29.520 --> 00:03:31.840
The other thing I like
about host discovery, one,

73
00:03:31.840 --> 00:03:34.940
I need to know what
devices are on my network.

74
00:03:34.940 --> 00:03:37.530
I need to see if there's any
devices that don't belong.

75
00:03:37.530 --> 00:03:41.610
And the other thing I'll need to do at
some point is start doing port scans.

76
00:03:41.610 --> 00:03:43.890
When we talk about hardening servers,

77
00:03:43.890 --> 00:03:48.540
hardening nodes of any kind,
one of the big things we talk about is

78
00:03:48.540 --> 00:03:50.680
eliminating services
that aren't necessary.

79
00:03:50.680 --> 00:03:52.620
Which means I'm gonna be doing port scans.

80
00:03:52.620 --> 00:03:54.000
We're gonna scan those machines and

81
00:03:54.000 --> 00:03:57.610
see what ports are opening, what
services are in their listening state.

82
00:03:57.610 --> 00:03:58.700
Which Nmap will do as well.

83
00:03:58.700 --> 00:04:01.550
But before we can do that,
we need find the hosts so

84
00:04:01.550 --> 00:04:04.490
that's where we're gonna start is
finding those hosts out there.

85
00:04:04.490 --> 00:04:06.760
And then we can worry about
the other stuff later.

86
00:04:06.760 --> 00:04:09.290
>> So I just yell at my computer now and
I say, okay computer.

87
00:04:09.290 --> 00:04:12.697
>> [LAUGH]
>> Nmap my network finds these things for

88
00:04:12.697 --> 00:04:13.496
me right?

89
00:04:13.496 --> 00:04:17.120
>> That's coming to a theater soon but
[LAUGH] not yet right.

90
00:04:17.120 --> 00:04:19.560
Maybe if we take that echo and
we hook it up to the thing.

91
00:04:19.560 --> 00:04:20.750
>> Yeah see we can make it happen.

92
00:04:20.750 --> 00:04:21.740
We have the technology.

93
00:04:21.740 --> 00:04:24.560
>> We could do it all right so
there's a new project for you guys and

94
00:04:24.560 --> 00:04:25.650
girls out there.

95
00:04:25.650 --> 00:04:28.950
>> Is a good echo to work with
Nmap to work with the scanning.

96
00:04:28.950 --> 00:04:32.240
All right but anyways now what we're gonna
do rather than holler we're gonna type.

97
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:36.340
So let's take a look at my screen here
I've got a install of Kali Linux.

98
00:04:36.340 --> 00:04:39.560
One of my favorite distros just because
it has a lot of the tools loaded up in

99
00:04:39.560 --> 00:04:40.980
there already.

100
00:04:40.980 --> 00:04:44.590
But it's definitely you can run
nmap on any flavor of Linux

101
00:04:44.590 --> 00:04:46.160
>> Just have to go out to nmap.org.

102
00:04:46.160 --> 00:04:50.150
Get your source files, compile it,
or do your app get, or

103
00:04:50.150 --> 00:04:52.640
I don't know, whatever you need to do for
your Linux distro.

104
00:04:52.640 --> 00:04:53.770
It also runs on Windows.

105
00:04:53.770 --> 00:04:55.080
We'll take a look at the Windows port,

106
00:04:55.080 --> 00:04:58.875
which is one of those
not as common things.

107
00:04:58.875 --> 00:05:01.360
Were it'll run on Linux and
it'll run on Windows, and

108
00:05:01.360 --> 00:05:03.050
it does a pretty good job on Windows.

109
00:05:03.050 --> 00:05:07.660
A lot of times the Windows port
of a Linux tool is Subpar.

110
00:05:07.660 --> 00:05:09.270
But not so with Nmap.

111
00:05:09.270 --> 00:05:12.550
We even get a gooey with Windows.

112
00:05:12.550 --> 00:05:14.502
And some of you out
there might be like yes,

113
00:05:14.502 --> 00:05:16.520
I'll just fast forward
until I get to that.

114
00:05:16.520 --> 00:05:18.790
>> Where's the graphical
version of that thing man?

115
00:05:18.790 --> 00:05:20.360
>> All right, so I'm sorry.

116
00:05:20.360 --> 00:05:22.490
Taylor's got my screen pulled up and
I just keep talking.

117
00:05:22.490 --> 00:05:24.190
Let's do some stuff here.

118
00:05:24.190 --> 00:05:28.140
So anyway Nmap,
I'm just gonna type Nmap and hit enter.

119
00:05:28.140 --> 00:05:32.780
You can do an dash h or an dash dash
help and you can get this same file.

120
00:05:32.780 --> 00:05:33.970
Let's take a look at it here.

121
00:05:33.970 --> 00:05:35.430
Scroll back up to the top and

122
00:05:35.430 --> 00:05:41.340
you can see some relatively extensive help
available right here from the command.

123
00:05:41.340 --> 00:05:42.760
You can always go out to nmap.org.

124
00:05:42.760 --> 00:05:45.270
We'll take a peek at their
website in a minute, and

125
00:05:45.270 --> 00:05:50.360
they've got their documentation out there,
and it's very extensive.

126
00:05:50.360 --> 00:05:54.700
But we're going to be focusing
in on host discovery here.

127
00:05:56.800 --> 00:06:02.660
And we'll be doing a ping scan,
which is gonna disable my port scan.

128
00:06:02.660 --> 00:06:06.240
Because at this point I don't wanna
spend time scanning ports yet,

129
00:06:06.240 --> 00:06:08.190
because I don't know
what hosts are out there.

130
00:06:08.190 --> 00:06:11.820
A port scan, depending on how
we set it up, scans ports and

131
00:06:11.820 --> 00:06:16.080
it could scan all 65,535 of those guys.

132
00:06:16.080 --> 00:06:18.330
Looking for services that are opening, and

133
00:06:18.330 --> 00:06:22.290
what I don't wanna do let's say
what's your average number class

134
00:06:22.290 --> 00:06:25.940
C maybe even a class B if we're
trying to use the classful system?

135
00:06:25.940 --> 00:06:27.020
254 hosts.

136
00:06:27.020 --> 00:06:29.520
We get to a class B.

137
00:06:29.520 --> 00:06:30.249
What is that, Daniel?

138
00:06:30.249 --> 00:06:32.780
16,777,000, something like that?

139
00:06:32.780 --> 00:06:33.640
>> That's a lot.

140
00:06:33.640 --> 00:06:34.700
Yeah, that's a lot.

141
00:06:34.700 --> 00:06:40.188
>> And doing a port scan on
65,000 ports on 16 million hosts,

142
00:06:40.188 --> 00:06:43.230
that's not going to be a good thing.

143
00:06:43.230 --> 00:06:47.080
So we definitely want to
first get live IP addresses.

144
00:06:47.080 --> 00:06:48.080
Because even in a class C,

145
00:06:48.080 --> 00:06:51.870
what are the odds that you are using
all of those IP addresses.

146
00:06:51.870 --> 00:06:55.723
It is doubtful that all 254 IP
addresses are up and listening,

147
00:06:55.723 --> 00:06:56.992
being used by a host.

148
00:06:56.992 --> 00:07:00.854
Because then you have no room left and
you are going to need a bigger subnet.

149
00:07:00.854 --> 00:07:04.139
So the first thing I would love to do
is just get a list of live hosts that I

150
00:07:04.139 --> 00:07:05.785
can then take on to do my port scan.

151
00:07:05.785 --> 00:07:13.480
So the SN, that's switch SN
is going to do my ping scan.

152
00:07:13.480 --> 00:07:14.990
Now Daniel do you remember
the old command for that?

153
00:07:14.990 --> 00:07:17.021
>> Yes, I think it was S capital P.

154
00:07:17.021 --> 00:07:19.865
[CROSSTALK]
>> The dash S,

155
00:07:19.865 --> 00:07:24.180
capital P is no longer
doing the ping scan.

156
00:07:24.180 --> 00:07:25.080
>> It still works I think.

157
00:07:25.080 --> 00:07:26.710
I think you can still actually use it.

158
00:07:26.710 --> 00:07:30.100
So if you'd played around with Nmap
before and you're used to that,

159
00:07:30.100 --> 00:07:31.410
it'll probably still work.

160
00:07:31.410 --> 00:07:35.100
Just start getting used to the SN
because that will eventually go away.

161
00:07:35.100 --> 00:07:35.970
>> Yeah, exactly.

162
00:07:35.970 --> 00:07:38.930
My guess is I don't know for
sure that Capital P,

163
00:07:38.930 --> 00:07:41.370
it'll start doing
something else within Nmap.

164
00:07:41.370 --> 00:07:41.980
>> Yeah, could be.

165
00:07:41.980 --> 00:07:43.620
>> Start running low on letters, and so.

166
00:07:43.620 --> 00:07:47.503
>> Boy, that'd be confusing if you were
super locked into SP as your ping scan,

167
00:07:47.503 --> 00:07:49.070
and then they change it on you.

168
00:07:49.070 --> 00:07:49.725
What are you doing?

169
00:07:49.725 --> 00:07:54.173
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so update your
scripts to reflect that new command.

170
00:07:54.173 --> 00:07:56.246
So that's the one we're gonna be doing.

171
00:07:56.246 --> 00:07:58.955
So let me clear out my screen here.

172
00:07:58.955 --> 00:08:03.133
So it's gonna be an end map and actually
you know what I'm gonna do for us Daniel,

173
00:08:03.133 --> 00:08:07.437
I'm gonna connect to a different network
real quick that has a little more activity

174
00:08:07.437 --> 00:08:08.220
going on.

175
00:08:08.220 --> 00:08:09.390
I already got it switched over.

176
00:08:09.390 --> 00:08:10.430
We are good to go there.

177
00:08:10.430 --> 00:08:11.960
>> You're being all prepared for show.

178
00:08:11.960 --> 00:08:17.143
>> I know.
Let's double check our Sometimes

179
00:08:17.143 --> 00:08:18.460
once in a while.

180
00:08:18.460 --> 00:08:23.380
Now you'll notice that I'm actually
on a class b if you will right?

181
00:08:23.380 --> 00:08:24.310
It's a 25525500.

182
00:08:24.310 --> 00:08:27.730
I'm not going to scan all of those hosts.

183
00:08:27.730 --> 00:08:34.810
It would just take even just doing
a discovery would take a long time so

184
00:08:34.810 --> 00:08:38.400
we're gonna trim it up a little bit,
but my command is going to be nmap.

185
00:08:38.400 --> 00:08:41.120
So that's the name of the tool
that we're gonna use and

186
00:08:41.120 --> 00:08:45.960
I want to do a -sn,
which is gonna be my ping sweep.

187
00:08:45.960 --> 00:08:46.710
All right.

188
00:08:46.710 --> 00:08:50.105
And you can see in my notes I
did the old school there -s.

189
00:08:50.105 --> 00:08:51.000
We'll change that up.

190
00:08:51.000 --> 00:08:55.145
We'll make the modern command here and
then the network address I want to scan

191
00:08:55.145 --> 00:09:01.778
10.0.14.0/24.

192
00:09:01.778 --> 00:09:04.950
We'll just do
>> 16.

193
00:09:04.950 --> 00:09:05.730
>> What's that?

194
00:09:05.730 --> 00:09:07.077
>> Your netmask is 16.

195
00:09:07.077 --> 00:09:08.041
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> But

196
00:09:08.041 --> 00:09:09.760
that does bring up a very good point.

197
00:09:09.760 --> 00:09:13.310
You don't have to use the net mask
that you happen to be on, right.

198
00:09:13.310 --> 00:09:16.115
As Daniel pointed out,
I'm on a 255.255.0.0 network but

199
00:09:16.115 --> 00:09:17.455
I don't want to scan all of that.

200
00:09:17.455 --> 00:09:20.440
>> Right, change it up a little bit.

201
00:09:20.440 --> 00:09:22.052
>> Maybe I've got [CROSSTALK], yeah,

202
00:09:22.052 --> 00:09:24.530
maybe I've got to break it up
to make it take less time.

203
00:09:24.530 --> 00:09:29.151
I've only got time to do a certain amount
right now or maybe I just wanna scan my

204
00:09:29.151 --> 00:09:34.060
server backbone, maybe that's what I
picked here as a small portion of it.

205
00:09:34.060 --> 00:09:37.820
I know all the servers have an IP
address 10.0.14 something and so

206
00:09:37.820 --> 00:09:42.760
I can cheat, if you will, by just
saying hey keep 10.0.14 the same right,

207
00:09:42.760 --> 00:09:44.810
that's what you're doing
with that next mask.

208
00:09:44.810 --> 00:09:47.230
Just scan this particular network.

209
00:09:47.230 --> 00:09:49.340
So now I’m only down to
254 possible hosts there,

210
00:09:49.340 --> 00:09:52.450
so it should be a lot quicker, all right?

211
00:09:52.450 --> 00:09:56.660
And I’ll go ahead and hit Enter and
we’ll let this guy run for

212
00:09:56.660 --> 00:10:00.300
a minute and there you can see,
256 IP addresses.

213
00:10:00.300 --> 00:10:04.360
Remember, there’s 254 possible hosts,
but there are 256

214
00:10:04.360 --> 00:10:09.190
total IP addresses if you
include the 0 and the 255.

215
00:10:09.190 --> 00:10:12.640
Scan 55 hosts took 2.3 seconds.

216
00:10:12.640 --> 00:10:14.290
As we go through these results,

217
00:10:14.290 --> 00:10:18.270
I know they're not real easy to
read because it's very packed.

218
00:10:18.270 --> 00:10:21.790
I'm going to show you a way we
can break this up in a minute but

219
00:10:21.790 --> 00:10:23.870
we'll go back up to the top here.

220
00:10:26.150 --> 00:10:27.650
There was my initial command.

221
00:10:27.650 --> 00:10:31.252
It says starting nmap and
then I can see the first one.

222
00:10:31.252 --> 00:10:34.800
Nmap scan for report 0.14.11.

223
00:10:34.800 --> 00:10:42.340
Host is up and it gives me the MAC address
and it tells me it thinks it's an Apple.

224
00:10:42.340 --> 00:10:44.410
>> It's probably a good guess,
since we run a lot of Macs here.

225
00:10:44.410 --> 00:10:47.631
>> We do run a lot of Macs here but
it's kinda cool that it's giving me

226
00:10:47.631 --> 00:10:50.574
a little bit of a guess there,
even just doing a ping sweep.

227
00:10:50.574 --> 00:10:53.648
Now in this case,
it's not doing a lot of interrogation.

228
00:10:53.648 --> 00:10:54.544
All right.

229
00:10:54.544 --> 00:11:00.200
I'll talk about doing an OS fingerprinting
here when we get into our port scanning.

230
00:11:00.200 --> 00:11:03.800
What it's doing right here
is it's looking at that,

231
00:11:03.800 --> 00:11:07.680
and gosh this would be a West question
because that actually has a name.

232
00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:11.920
The MAC address, the first six
digits are the organizational ID.

233
00:11:11.920 --> 00:11:16.820
>> Yeah, the organizational OUI or
unit identifier or something like that?

234
00:11:16.820 --> 00:11:19.040
>> Yes, something like that.

235
00:11:19.040 --> 00:11:19.960
We should watch his show.

236
00:11:19.960 --> 00:11:20.600
>> Westnotes.

237
00:11:20.600 --> 00:11:23.660
He actually said it today, after.

238
00:11:23.660 --> 00:11:24.613
>> [LAUGH] But that first part,

239
00:11:24.613 --> 00:11:26.980
that's a block that gets assigned
to a particular vendor, right?

240
00:11:26.980 --> 00:11:31.580
And they can use the last six digits for
their different devices or what have you.

241
00:11:31.580 --> 00:11:33.330
>> Organizational unique identifier.

242
00:11:33.330 --> 00:11:36.820
>> OUI.
>> That's it, how my brain works.

243
00:11:36.820 --> 00:11:39.920
>> You rock.
And that's really what it's doing here.

244
00:11:39.920 --> 00:11:44.130
It knows that hey,
this has been assigned to Apple and

245
00:11:44.130 --> 00:11:46.390
I think I've frozen up my machine.

246
00:11:46.390 --> 00:11:47.880
There it goes.

247
00:11:47.880 --> 00:11:51.010
This one evidently belongs
to Hewlett Packard.

248
00:11:51.010 --> 00:11:52.910
So that's really all it's looking at.

249
00:11:52.910 --> 00:11:55.700
It's just a guess and
if something was being spoofed or forged,

250
00:11:55.700 --> 00:11:56.830
it would fake this out.

251
00:11:56.830 --> 00:12:00.020
So don't take that-
>> As the gospel of Paul [LAUGH].

252
00:12:00.020 --> 00:12:02.080
>> Yes, you know, look okay,
that's interesting,

253
00:12:02.080 --> 00:12:06.060
it probably is an apple if all I have
are legitimate devices on my network but

254
00:12:06.060 --> 00:12:09.450
again, don't take it for being truthful.

255
00:12:09.450 --> 00:12:13.830
And you can see it's gone down through but
I guess the point here that I would like

256
00:12:13.830 --> 00:12:20.170
to make is the fact that I
only have 55 hosts up, right?

257
00:12:20.170 --> 00:12:23.040
Out of 256, so I do my math real quick.

258
00:12:23.040 --> 00:12:24.680
That's 201.

259
00:12:24.680 --> 00:12:26.070
Right, that aren't being used.

260
00:12:26.070 --> 00:12:26.570
>> Yeah.

261
00:12:26.570 --> 00:12:31.960
>> So now, if I was doing a port scan, and
I was scanning all 65,000 some odd ports,

262
00:12:31.960 --> 00:12:37.900
I'd be scanning 201 IP addresses
that weren't even there, right.

263
00:12:37.900 --> 00:12:39.600
So a complete waste of time.

264
00:12:39.600 --> 00:12:42.140
>> Yeah, the good news is that
people at Nmap, they know this.

265
00:12:42.140 --> 00:12:46.570
This kind of thing happens and
the default setting of nmap is to,

266
00:12:46.570 --> 00:12:52.290
if it replies to a ping's response, then
yes it's alive and go ahead and scan it.

267
00:12:52.290 --> 00:12:56.550
If it doesn't, then move on to the next
guy but it still has to check and

268
00:12:56.550 --> 00:12:57.190
see if it's still alive.

269
00:12:57.190 --> 00:12:58.940
If you've already done this work,

270
00:12:58.940 --> 00:13:03.290
you save the scanning portion of your
proceedings a lot of time and effort.

271
00:13:03.290 --> 00:13:04.340
>> Exactly right, Daniel.

272
00:13:04.340 --> 00:13:06.960
It does do a basically a phase process.

273
00:13:06.960 --> 00:13:09.940
End map does a discovery phase and
then a scanning phase and

274
00:13:09.940 --> 00:13:12.500
we will definitely get into
that when we get into scanning

275
00:13:12.500 --> 00:13:14.740
cuz there are times when I
don't want it to do that.

276
00:13:14.740 --> 00:13:19.000
I wanna scan because we do have to worry
about what if something was blocking.

277
00:13:19.000 --> 00:13:23.390
Like if it's not responding to pings,
is it going to reply to this?

278
00:13:23.390 --> 00:13:26.290
Right.
What if there's a firewall between me and

279
00:13:26.290 --> 00:13:29.770
the destination that's blocking
that particular type of traffic?

280
00:13:29.770 --> 00:13:33.330
Or there's a firewall in the host
that's blocking the ping package,

281
00:13:33.330 --> 00:13:35.400
which a lot of hosts do, right?

282
00:13:35.400 --> 00:13:39.050
A lot of Windows by default will
start blocking those pings.

283
00:13:39.050 --> 00:13:41.920
So when it does this ping sweep,
what it's really doing.

284
00:13:41.920 --> 00:13:44.180
Is it's doing an ICMP ping and

285
00:13:44.180 --> 00:13:49.870
it's also sending a TCPIP packet to
port 80 by default which you can change.

286
00:13:49.870 --> 00:13:53.690
So it's doing two discovery methods there,
sending an ICMP and

287
00:13:53.690 --> 00:13:57.890
it's doing a TCP send request and
if it's a send,

288
00:13:57.890 --> 00:14:02.940
no it's an acknowledgment, it's either
a send or an ak packet that it sends.

289
00:14:02.940 --> 00:14:06.910
And it sends it to port 80 by default,
which you can change as well and

290
00:14:06.910 --> 00:14:11.680
what it's saying is hey if it
sends me back a reset or close,

291
00:14:11.680 --> 00:14:15.940
well it's not running a web server but hey
I know it's up because it responded to me.

292
00:14:15.940 --> 00:14:17.510
If it sends back an open,

293
00:14:17.510 --> 00:14:20.310
I've got a web server running then
hey I know it's up and running.

294
00:14:20.310 --> 00:14:23.700
If it doesn't send anything back,
then it's probably not a live host.

295
00:14:23.700 --> 00:14:30.350
So it does do a double check there for
these live hosts, all right?

296
00:14:30.350 --> 00:14:32.100
Now, the next thing I wanna show you here,
and

297
00:14:32.100 --> 00:14:35.990
this will kinda help prepare us for
our scanning phases, and

00:14:35.990 --> 00:14:38.880
this is good information but it's just

00:15:05.010 --> 00:15:09.150

we can do the on which is normal output,

looks just like this nmap output

00:15:12.110 --> 00:15:14.980

00:15:23.730 --> 00:15:26.410

00:15:29.020 --> 00:15:33.150
dash G, which is gripable, all right?

00:15:33.150 --> 00:15:36.560
Or you can do an o dash a which is all.

00:15:36.560 --> 00:15:39.150
It does the three major formats at once.

00:15:39.150 --> 00:15:40.932
It would skip the script kiddie.

00:15:42.769 --> 00:15:47.693
You just give it a filename and

00:15:47.693 --> 00:15:52.718
All right, so let's close that

be format cuz now I can manipulate

00:16:36.460 --> 00:16:41.400

00:16:41.400 --> 00:16:46.430
But now it's on one line and I've got

00:16:46.430 --> 00:16:51.590

00:16:51.590 --> 00:16:58.640
And the idea here is that when I do a port

00:16:58.640 --> 00:17:01.140

by default that's what it does.

00:17:01.140 --> 00:17:02.860
But there might be times when you've got,

00:18:39.500 --> 00:18:46.461

00:18:46.461 --> 00:18:49.220

00:19:07.160 --> 00:19:11.220
So we grep for the word up, and

00:19:11.220 --> 00:19:15.438

a switch D is actually gonna be a space.

00:19:15.438 --> 00:19:18.290
So I got a quote space quote there.

00:19:19.560 --> 00:19:24.560
And then we're going to pick

And then I'm gonna send that output to,

00:23:33.320 --> 00:23:36.300
>> Yeah, Mike, it's a little tiny though,

451
00:23:36.300 --> 00:23:39.460
do you think you can make that a little
bigger for our viewing audience out there?

452
00:23:39.460 --> 00:23:42.846
>> Let's see if I can work my magic cuz
I can't see it either to be honest.

453
00:23:42.846 --> 00:23:43.470
>> [LAUGH] It's really small.
>> So

454
00:23:43.470 --> 00:23:46.001
we'll zoom in up here and
how's that, a little better?

455
00:23:46.001 --> 00:23:49.527
All right, so good old Zenmap
wants to know what my target is.

456
00:23:49.527 --> 00:23:52.402
All right, so let's pick a target.

457
00:23:52.402 --> 00:23:55.940
I've got another host
we're gonna hit here.

458
00:23:55.940 --> 00:24:00.486
Actually we get to do that same network,
it didn't take that long.

459
00:24:00.486 --> 00:24:02.948
Let's do 10.0.14.

460
00:24:02.948 --> 00:24:04.811
In fact, there she is in my list.

461
00:24:04.811 --> 00:24:10.879
And my tab autofill didn't like that.

462
00:24:10.879 --> 00:24:14.073
Let's add a 0/24, good old GUIs.

463
00:24:14.073 --> 00:24:15.277
Gotta click, gotta use that mouse.

464
00:24:15.277 --> 00:24:16.144
>> Right.
>> It's almost like

465
00:24:16.144 --> 00:24:16.728
they're forcing you to.

466
00:24:16.728 --> 00:24:17.788
>> Like get off of that keyboard, boy!

467
00:24:17.788 --> 00:24:22.600
>> But do you see what's
happening underneath, right here?

468
00:24:22.600 --> 00:24:24.730
That's the command that
it's going to execute.

469
00:24:24.730 --> 00:24:30.545
So if I change this, 15.,
notice how it's changing here, as well?

470
00:24:30.545 --> 00:24:32.926
So this will help you learn.

471
00:24:32.926 --> 00:24:39.770
You can come in here and do, okay, I know
what I want, /24, and it adds this 4.

472
00:24:39.770 --> 00:24:41.946
It builds that command for you.

473
00:24:41.946 --> 00:24:43.727
Now it's got a couple of other
things in there by default.

474
00:24:43.727 --> 00:24:47.010
It's got a -T4, that's for timing.

475
00:24:47.010 --> 00:24:48.242
That'll make it go faster.

476
00:24:48.242 --> 00:24:49.935
It's not as stealthy, but

477
00:24:49.935 --> 00:24:54.420
it won't pause as long between
packets that it's sending out.

478
00:24:54.420 --> 00:24:55.285
The -A, and

479
00:24:55.285 --> 00:25:00.019
we'll talk all about this again when
we get into actual port scanning.

480
00:25:00.019 --> 00:25:01.226
-A includes versioning and OS detection.

481
00:25:01.226 --> 00:25:03.177
-v for verbose.

482
00:25:03.177 --> 00:25:08.404
I'm gonna take those out,
because I don't want them at this point.

483
00:25:08.404 --> 00:25:12.193
I just wanna show you
simple host discovery.

484
00:25:12.193 --> 00:25:12.816
Let me back out.

485
00:25:12.816 --> 00:25:17.497
There are some profiles over here that
I can choose from, all right, and

486
00:25:17.497 --> 00:25:20.270
these are just pre-built commands.

487
00:25:20.270 --> 00:25:21.865
So maybe I'm again, learning.

488
00:25:21.865 --> 00:25:24.840
I know I wanna do a ping scan, so
I am just gonna grab that one.

489
00:25:24.840 --> 00:25:27.163
And let's see what it did.

490
00:25:27.163 --> 00:25:33.019
Notice it added the -sn just
like we did in Linux, right?

491
00:25:33.019 --> 00:25:40.110
So if I zoom back out, and I go ahead and
click Scan, it should start that scan.

492
00:25:43.435 --> 00:25:44.270
Where is my window?

493
00:25:44.270 --> 00:25:44.820
There we go.

494
00:25:44.820 --> 00:25:45.586
Did I say scan?

495
00:25:45.586 --> 00:25:46.321
There we go.

496
00:25:46.321 --> 00:25:50.776
It needed to be clicked twice,
you know how these GUIs are.

497
00:25:50.776 --> 00:25:54.708
[LAUGH] All right, so it's starting Nmap
and I'll zoom in as it's rolling here.

498
00:25:54.708 --> 00:25:58.900
And same type of results,
nmap scan, Host is up.

499
00:25:58.900 --> 00:26:01.400
So that's all it's doing is
it's showing me my live host.

500
00:26:01.400 --> 00:26:02.960
That is pretty.

501
00:26:02.960 --> 00:26:04.676
I've got this nice area over here.

502
00:26:04.676 --> 00:26:06.990
Let me see if I can make
that a little bit wider.

503
00:26:06.990 --> 00:26:10.062
>> I just like how the output area
is very similar to what we see in

504
00:26:10.062 --> 00:26:11.398
a terminal environment.

505
00:26:11.398 --> 00:26:12.626
>> Yep.
>> Keeps that level

506
00:26:12.626 --> 00:26:13.952
of comfortability for us.

507
00:26:13.952 --> 00:26:17.680
>> It does, and
it has some neat things in here.

508
00:26:17.680 --> 00:26:22.875
Once we start doing actual port scans,
we'll see a nice list of ports.

509
00:26:22.875 --> 00:26:27.110
Look, as I click on these individual
hosts, it could show me the information.

510
00:26:27.110 --> 00:26:34.199
It'll actually print out or
create a topology, which is crazy, crazy.

511
00:26:34.199 --> 00:26:35.279
It's tricky to get.

512
00:26:35.279 --> 00:26:38.023
My zoom level is way up here.

513
00:26:38.023 --> 00:26:39.552
Where is my zoom?

514
00:26:39.552 --> 00:26:45.852
Yeah, we're not gonna
mess with that right now.

515
00:26:45.852 --> 00:26:47.674
>> [LAUGH] [CROSSTALK]
>> Before I do, there's my controls and

516
00:26:47.674 --> 00:26:48.332
there's my zoom.

517
00:26:48.332 --> 00:26:52.712
Yeah, you can start zooming in and
can start creating topologies.

518
00:26:52.712 --> 00:26:55.240
It's gonna be a pretty boring
topology here because they're all

519
00:26:55.240 --> 00:26:58.120
on the same subnet, so
it just looks silly.

520
00:26:58.120 --> 00:27:02.296
But in a network that you are unfamiliar
with or you've got a heavily routed

521
00:27:02.296 --> 00:27:05.892
network, that topology generator
is pretty cool, all right?

522
00:27:05.892 --> 00:27:09.303
So there's a lot of other information,
but since we only did a ping sweep,

523
00:27:09.303 --> 00:27:11.480
we're not getting any
of the information yet.

524
00:27:11.480 --> 00:27:13.830
It's just saying, hey,
they're up or they're not up.

525
00:27:13.830 --> 00:27:16.160
And it's only showing me
the ones that are up.

526
00:27:16.160 --> 00:27:17.380
So there you have Nmap.

527
00:27:17.380 --> 00:27:19.410
We've got it in all of
our different platforms.

528
00:27:19.410 --> 00:27:23.510
We saw it on Linux, running it in
Cali from the command line there.

529
00:27:23.510 --> 00:27:28.710
We saw it on Windows,
using both ZenMap, the GUI.

530
00:27:28.710 --> 00:27:32.740
We saw that the command line was going to
be no different on Windows either, but

531
00:27:32.740 --> 00:27:34.910
using Nmap to do host discovery.

532
00:27:34.910 --> 00:27:37.120
Find out what the heck is
out there on your network.

533
00:27:37.120 --> 00:27:38.887
>> That's right.
Old venerable Nmap comes to

534
00:27:38.887 --> 00:27:39.980
the rescue yet again.

535
00:27:39.980 --> 00:27:41.880
It is something that's tried and true.

536
00:27:41.880 --> 00:27:46.320
And you will encounter and
use it as a security professional up here

537
00:27:46.320 --> 00:27:49.110
trying to implement more
security in your environment.

538
00:27:49.110 --> 00:27:51.130
So just dig in your heels.

539
00:27:51.130 --> 00:27:54.548
The man page is your friend
when it comes to Nmap.

540
00:27:54.548 --> 00:27:57.700
A lot of great documentation out there for
it as well.

541
00:27:57.700 --> 00:28:00.889
That being said, Mike, it looks like
we are out of time for this episode.

542
00:28:00.889 --> 00:28:02.279
But perfectly timed, though,

543
00:28:02.279 --> 00:28:04.860
because you were done showing
us how to do host discovery.

544
00:28:04.860 --> 00:28:06.176
>> [LAUGH] We try, we try.
>> That's right, so

545
00:28:06.176 --> 00:28:10.221
everybody run out there, grab your copy of
Nmap, start scanning your networks, and

546
00:28:10.221 --> 00:28:13.120
find hosts on them so
that you can start mapping it out.

547
00:28:13.120 --> 00:28:15.304
Very cool stuff, thanks for
joining us today.

548
00:28:15.304 --> 00:28:16.186
But we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

549
00:28:16.186 --> 00:28:18.470
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

550
00:28:18.470 --> 00:28:19.414
>> And I'm Mike Rodrick.

551
00:28:19.414 --> 00:28:20.649
>> And we'll see you next time.

552
00:28:20.649 --> 00:28:27.657
[MUSIC]

553
00:28:27.657 --> 00:28:29.675
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at port scanning using the venerable Nmap scanner in both Linux and Windows.
episodes.title: Port Scanning

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at using the OpenVAS vulnerability scanner to automatically detect known vulnerabilities in your environment.
episodes.title: OpenVAS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at the Microsoft Baseline Security Analyzer which is used to uncover common security misconfigurations in a Microsoft environment.
episodes.title: MBSA

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at using the Nikto web app vulnerability scanner.
episodes.title: Nikto

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at using Sparta to speed up the process of scanning and formatting output for ease of reading.
episodes.title: This is Sparta

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at using Burp Suite web application scanner and proxy for testing the security of our web apps. Watch as they show you how to use Burp to intercept web traffic and even perform a dictionary-based password attack.
episodes.title: Burp Suite

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike explore common tools, techniques, and practices used in the pursuit of securing your environment. Here they specifically look at using the OWASP ZAP web application scanner and proxy for testing the security of our web apps. Watch as they show you how to use ZAP to scan a web app with its built-in vulnerability scanner, how to set up ZAP as a web proxy, and even perform a dictionary-based password attack.
episodes.title: OWASP Zap

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike take a look at a very common attack performed on a great many websites and databases known as SQL injection. They describe the basic characteristics of the attack as well as demonstrating some of the many possible outcomes that can result.
episodes.title: SQL Injection

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike talk about a way to automate a very common attack performed on a great many websites and databases known as SQL injection. They dive into a technology known as sqlmap that helps to perform some steps to perform the attack.
episodes.title: sqlmap

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike talk about the basics surrounding password cracking. They will discuss were we can look to find passwords, such as the SAM file in Windows local account, NTDS.dit for Active Directory accounts and /etc/shadow for Linux systems. The types of attacks that can be performed on passwords such as dictionary attacks, the CPU intensive brute force attack, and the hybrid attack. They will also dive into the software used to crack passwords.
episodes.title: Password Cracking Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Mike talk about a popular free password cracking software known as hash cat. They discuss the major features of hash cat as well as summarizing the algorithms and attack types. They explore the basics behind the interface with a live demonstration to help the viewers with a hands-on approach.
episodes.title: Hashcat
